content: The Act may be cited as the "Department of Homeland Security Financial Accountability Act". The Congress recognizes the importance of financial management leadership within the Department of Homeland Security. The Chief Financial Officer must play a key role in the department's management structure. The Chief Financial Officers Act of 1990 requires the CFO of each federal executive department to be a Presidential appointee reporting directly to the Secretary on financial matters. Amendments are needed to include the Department of Homeland Security in these provisions. The Department of Homeland Security needs a strong Chief Financial Officer to consolidate financial management operations and ensure management control systems are designed to achieve its mission of preventing terrorist attacks and minimizing damage. The Chief Financial Officers Act of 1990 requires agency CFOs to report directly to the Secretary on financial matters. Amendments are needed to include the Department of Homeland Security in these provisions. The Chief Financial Officers Act of 1990 mandates agency CFOs to enhance financial information for agency managers and Congress. It requires agency financial management systems to measure performance systematically. For the Department of Homeland Security, management control systems must align with homeland security strategy to address terrorism risks effectively. CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER OF THE DEPARTMENT OF HOMELAND SECURITY. The Chief Financial Officers Act of 1990 mandates agency CFOs to enhance financial information for agency managers and Congress, aligning with homeland security strategy to address terrorism risks effectively. The Department of Homeland Security is required to appoint a Chief Financial Officer within 180 days of the enactment of this Act. The current CFO or their replacement can continue to serve in that position. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to include a Chief Financial Officer position as mandated by the Chief Financial Officers Act of 1990. The current CFO can continue to serve until a successor is confirmed or designated. The CFO's responsibilities are specified in chapter 9 of title 31, United States Code, and they report to the Under Secretary for Management. FEMA's section 901(b)(2) is also amended to reorganize subparagraphs. The CFO's responsibilities are specified in chapter 9 of title 31, United States Code, and they report to the Under Secretary for Management. FEMA's section 901(b)(2) is also amended to reorganize subparagraphs. The functions of the Chief Financial Officer of the Department of Homeland Security are outlined in section 4. The Secretary of Homeland Security is required to submit a performance and accountability report each fiscal year that includes a program performance report for the Department of Homeland Security. The report must also contain an audit opinion on the Department's internal controls over financial reporting and implement management controls reflecting the latest homeland security strategy. The Secretary of Homeland Security must include audit opinions in performance reports for fiscal years after 2005 and assert internal controls for financial reporting in the performance and accountability report for fiscal year 2005. Audit opinions on internal controls over financial reporting by Chief Financial Officer Agencies are also required. The Chief Financial Officers Council and the President's Council on Integrity and Efficiency will conduct a study on the costs and benefits of requiring listed agencies to obtain audit opinions on their internal controls over financial reporting. A report on the study results will be submitted to relevant committees and the Comptroller General of the United States. The Comptroller General will analyze the information provided in a report within 90 days and report the findings to relevant committees. SEC. 5. FUTURE YEARS HOMELAND SECURITY PROGRAM AND HOMELAND SECURITY STRATEGY. Section 874 of the Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to include requirements for the Future Years Homeland Security Program, which must align with the Department's homeland security strategy and resource allocations. Establishment of Office of Program Analysis and Evaluation. Section 702 of the Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to establish an Office of Program Analysis and Evaluation within the Department to analyze and evaluate plans, programs, and budgets in relation to homeland security objectives. The Office of Program Analysis and Evaluation within the Department analyzes and evaluates plans, programs, and budgets in relation to homeland security objectives. It develops alternative plans, performs analyses, establishes policies, oversees integration of planning systems, reviews budget requirements, and provides guidance for development. The Office of Program Analysis and Evaluation oversees the development of the Future Years Homeland Security Program, ensures accurate cost presentation of Department programs, prepares annual performance plans and reports, promotes analytical tools for resource allocation, and handles other responsibilities delegated by the Secretary for effective program analysis and evaluation. The Office of Program Analysis and Evaluation is overseen by a Director who reports to the Chief Financial Officer and may have their functions reallocated by the Secretary in accordance with specific regulations. SEC. 7. Notification regarding transfer or reprogramming of funds for the Department of Homeland Security requires the Chief Financial Officer to notify specific congressional committees when appropriations are transferred or reprogrammed.
